item.title: Cart pendulum Part 1: Lagrangian mechanics
item.description:
Introduction

A cart pendulum is a device consisting of a movable cart with a pendulum attached to it. In this article, I am going to discuss the dynamics of one such device. The cart would be constrained to move only along a s straight line such that it lies in the pendulum’s plane of motion. This is illustrated in the cover picture.

The dynamics would be described by a set of differential equations and these equations would be derived using two formulations of mechanics: Lagrangian dynamics and Hamiltonian dynamics. I omit deriving these equations using Newton’s second law because it is very tedious and increasing the chances of mistakes sneaking in. Along with theory, a jupyter notebook would be provided with necessary code to derive these equations symbolically in python link.



System setup

The static configuration of the system is defined by two variables; $x$ the position of the cart relative to a reference and $\theta$ the angle between the pendulum and the vertical axis ($y$-axis) . Unlike a regular pendulum, the angle $\theta$ is measured from the positive $y$-axis. In a later article, we will discuss how to stabilises the vertical upright position of the pendulum, so defining this position as zero would become convinient. The system setup is represented concisely in the following image.

The system is this case is simplified. We assume the system experiences no friction or air drag. Additionally the pendulum is assumted to be point mass $m_p$ attached to a mass less rod of length $l$. The pendulum is attached the cart of mass $m_c$.


Verification

Before we go any further, we need to device some tests to verify whether the model we get represents the cart pendulum. It is always wise to have ways to test the answer before we get it. Doing this step beforehand ensures we are not biased by the answers. The following tests may not necessarily prove the correctness of the answer, but serves to indicate whether the solution is wrong. In other words, if the solution fails these tests, then the solution is wrong.

Test 1

When the mass of the pendulum is very small compared to the cart, or when $m_p \ll m_c \rightarrow m_p / m_c \approx 0$, we should be able to recover the dynamics of a simple pendulum

Test 2

In this system, the cart-pendulum experiences no horizontal force, unless a control force acts on it. In this article, the control input is 0. So the horizontal position of the centre of mass of the system should remain at rest or uniform motion.

Lagrangian Mechanics

Lagrangian Mechanics is a formulation of mechanics which uses the principle of least action [1]. Action is defined in terms of a quantity called the lagrangian (represented using $L$). The Lagrangian $L$ is defined as $L = T - V$ where $T$ is the kinetic energy of the system and $V$ is the potential energy of the system. Please visit [2] for a deep discussion on the Lagrangian Formalism.

Setting up the Lagrangian

The quantities $L$, $T$ and $V$ are functions of the generalised states (the generalised positions $\textbf{q}$ and velocities $\dot{\textbf{q}}$) and time $t$. In our case the generalised positions are $x$ and $\theta$, while the generalised velocities are $\dot{x}$ and $\dot{\theta}$. Let use now express these quantities in terms of the state variables.


Position of the cart
$(x,0)$

Velocity of the cart
$(\dot{x}, 0)$

Kinetic energy of the cart
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_c\dot{x}^2$

Potential energy of the cart
0

Position of the pendulum
$(x + l\sin(\theta), l\cos(\theta))$

Velocity of the pendulum
$(\dot{x} + \dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta), -\dot{\theta}l\sin(\theta))$

Kinetic energy of the pendulum
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_p((\dot{x} + \dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta))^2 + (-\dot{\theta}l\sin(\theta)^2))$
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_p(\dot{x}^2 + 2\dot{x}\dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta) + (\dot{\theta}l)^2)$

Potential energy of the pendulum
$-m_pgl\cos(\theta)$

Total kinetic energy, $T$
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_c\dot{x}^2 + \cfrac{1}{2}m_p(\dot{x}^2 + 2\dot{x}\dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta) + (\dot{\theta}l)^2)$

Total potential energy, $V$
$-m_pgl\cos(\theta)$

The Lagrangian, $L$
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_c\dot{x}^2 + \cfrac{1}{2}m_p(\dot{x}^2 + 2\dot{x}\dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta) + (\dot{\theta}l)^2) + m_pgl\cos(\theta)$

Dynamical equations

The dynamical equations are derived using the Euler–Lagrange equation [1]. It is shown below

$\begin{equation} \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t}\left(\cfrac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_j}\right) - \cfrac{\partial L}{\partial q_j} = Q_{nc} \end{equation}$
Here $Q_{nc}$ represents and non-conservative force acting on the system, $q_j$ represents a single generalised position and $\dot{q_j}$ the corresponding velocity. The non non-conservative could be a control input. Plugging in our Lagrangian into the Euler–Lagrange equation, we the get the following
$m_c \ddot{x}+m_p\left(-l \sin (\theta)\left(\dot{ \theta}\right)^2+l \cos (\theta) \ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x}\right) = 0$ $l m_p\left(-g \sin (\theta)+l \ddot{ \theta} +\cos (\theta) \ddot{ x}\right) = 0$

Now these equations form a system of second order differential equations which describe the dynamics of the cart-pendulum. These become more useful when we solve for $\ddot{x}$ and $\ddot{\theta}$. One, we can study the acceleration of the centre of mass and two, with some additional modification we can numerically integrate them. So, solving these equations for $\ddot{x}$ and $\ddot{x}$ yields

$\ddot{x} = \cfrac{g m_p \sin (2 \theta)+2 l m_p \sin (\theta)\left(\dot{ \theta}\right)^2}{2(m_c+m_p \sin ^2(\theta))}$
$\ddot{\theta} =-\cfrac{2g m_c \sin (\theta)+2g m_p \sin (\theta)+l m_p \sin (2 \theta)\left(\dot{ \theta}\right)^2}{2l\left(m_c+m_p \sin ^2(\theta)\right)}$

Verifying: test 1

Divide the numerator and denominator with $m_c$ so we can use $m_p / m_c \approx 0$. This leads to the following

$\ddot{x} = \cfrac{g \mathbf{m_p/m_c} \sin (2 \theta)+2 l \mathbf{m_p/m_c} \sin (\theta)\left(\dot{ \theta}\right)^2}{2(1+\mathbf{m_p/m_c} \sin ^2(\theta))} = 0$
$\ddot{\theta} =-\frac{2g \sin (\theta)+2g \mathbf{m_p/m_c} \sin (\theta)-l \mathbf{m_p/m_c} \sin (2 \theta)\left(\dot{ \theta}\right)^2}{2l\left(1+\mathbf{m_p/m_c} \sin ^2(\theta)\right)} = -\cfrac{g}{l}\sin(\theta)$

We can see that the equations we derived pass this test. When the mass of the pendulum is negligible compared ot the cart, the cart acceleration is 0, it remains in place and the pendulum behaves like a simple pendulum.

Verifying: test 2

Before we proceed, we need to find the expression for the centre of mass, specifically the x component

Center of mass position, x
$(m_c x_c + m_p x_p)/(m_c + m_p)$

Differntiating this twice with time yields

$\cfrac{m_c \ddot{ x}+m_p\left(-l \sin (\theta)\left(\dot{ \theta}\right)^2+l \cos (\theta) \ddot{ \theta}+\ddot{ x}\right)}{m_c+m_p}$

You will notice that the numerator is one of the equations we get after plugging in the Lagrangian in the Euler-Lagrange equation. So this evaluate to 0, passing our test.

Why did this happen? Physically, no horizontal force acts on the system. In terms of the Lagrangian mechanics, we can explain this as follows. The Lagrangian is independent of $x$, so differentiaing it with respect to $x$ yields 0. In other words

$\begin{equation} \cfrac{\partial L}{\partial x} = 0 \end{equation}$

Plugging this in the Euler-Lagrange equation we get

$\begin{equation} \cfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t}\left(\cfrac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right) = 0 \end{equation}$

This implies, the quantity $\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}$ is a constant of the system. In the next article, regarding Hamiltonian dynamics, we will see that this quantity is called generalised momentum conjugate to $x$.

Conclusion

This article gave a brief discussion on deriving the dynamics of a cart-pendulum using the Lagrangian formulation. The code I used to derive the equations are given in this link link. In the next article we will explore the use of the Hamiltonian framework to derive the governing equations.

Reference

[1] Wikipedia: Lagrangian mechanics [2] Classical Mechanics: Lagrangian formalism, V Balakrishnan

item.title: Cart pendulum Part 2: Hamiltonian mechanics
item.description:
Introduction

In the last article, we derived the dynamical equations of the cart pendulum using the Lagrangian formulation. In this cart, we will use an alternate formulation called Hamiltonian mechanics to derive the dynamical equations. Although the resulting equations may not be same, rest assured it describes the same dynamics. The code used to derive these equations are hosted here.



System setup

This article follows the same convention for defining the static configuration of the system. It is defined by two variables; $x$ the position of the cart relative to a reference and $\theta$ the angle between the pendulum and the vertical axis ($y$-axis) . Unlike a regular pendulum, the angle $\theta$ is measured from the positive $y$-axis. The system setup is represented concisely in the following image.

The system is this case is simplified. We assume the system experiences no friction or air drag. Additionally the pendulum is assumted to be point mass $m_p$ attached to a mass less rod of length $l$. The pendulum is attached the cart of mass $m_c$.


Hamiltonian Mechanics

Hamiltonian mechanics is an alternate formulation of mechanics based on Lagrangian mechanics[1]. It replaces the generalised veolcity with the generalised momentum in the governing equations. Interestingly, it bridges classical mechanics and quantum mechanics. [2] is an excellent lecture on Hamiltonian mechanics. Please note may not necessarily be equal to the mechanical momentum $p=mv$ in a system. This was the first mistake I made, when I wrote the code.

Setting up the Hamiltonian

The quantities $L$, $T$ and $V$ are functions of the generalised states (the generalised positions $\textbf{q}$ and velocities $\dot{\textbf{q}}$) and time $t$. Additionally, $\textbf{p}$ represents the generalised momenta. To get the Hamiltonian, we perform a Legendre transformation on the Lnagrangian.

The differential of the Langrangian is given by the following

$ dL = \cfrac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}} d \dot{q} + \cfrac{\partial L}{\partial q} d q + \cfrac{\partial L}{\partial t} d t $


Now, compare $\frac{dP}{dt}= F$ and $\frac{d}{d t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}\right) = \frac{\partial L}{\partial q} + Q_n$. We see that the $P$ and $\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}$ occupy the same position. So we call $\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}$ the generalised momentum $p$. Now, we want a quantity $H = H(q,p,t)$. This is where the Legendre transformation comes in and it is shown below.

$ \begin{equation} H = \textbf{p}\dot{\textbf{q}} - L \tag{1} \end{equation} $

Note that we solve the equations $p = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}$ to express $\dot{q}$ in terms of $p$ and substitute in the equation (1), to express $H$ as a function of $q$ $p$ and $t$ alone. It will turn out that the Hamiltonian is the total energy of mechanical systems

We have to go through with this convoluted process because the generalised momenta need not be apparent and so it will not be possible to express the kinetic energy using $p$. These steps are illustrated for the cart pendulum below.


Position of the cart
$(x,0)$

Velocity of the cart
$(\dot{x}, 0)$

Kinetic energy of the cart
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_c\dot{x}^2$

Potential energy of the cart
0

Position of the pendulum
$(x + l\sin(\theta), l\cos(\theta))$

Velocity of the pendulum
$(\dot{x} + \dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta), -\dot{\theta}l\sin(\theta))$

Kinetic energy of the pendulum
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_p((\dot{x} + \dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta))^2 + (-\dot{\theta}l\sin(\theta)^2))$
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_p(\dot{x}^2 + 2\dot{x}\dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta) + (\dot{\theta}l)^2)$

Potential energy of the pendulum
$-m_pgl\cos(\theta)$

Total kinetic energy, $T$
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_c\dot{x}^2 + \cfrac{1}{2}m_p(\dot{x}^2 + 2\dot{x}\dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta) + (\dot{\theta}l)^2)$

Total potential energy, $V$
$-m_pgl\cos(\theta)$

The Lagrangian, $L$
$\cfrac{1}{2}m_c\dot{x}^2 + \cfrac{1}{2}m_p(\dot{x}^2 + 2\dot{x}\dot{\theta}l\cos(\theta) + (\dot{\theta}l)^2) + m_pgl\cos(\theta)$

The generalised momenta $\begin{equation} p_1 = m_c \ddot{x}+m_p\left(-l \sin (\theta)\left(\dot{ \theta}\right)^2+l \cos (\theta) \ddot{\theta}+\ddot{x}\right) \end{equation}$

$ p_2 = m_pl\left(l \dot{\theta} +\cos \left(\theta\right) \dot{x} \right) $

You can observe that $p_1$ is the momentum of the center of the mass along the $x$ axis while $p_2$ is the momentum along the $\theta$ axis. Now these equations can be solved and substituted to get the Hamiltonian as shown below.

The Hamiltonian, $H$
$ \frac{g l^3 m_c m_p^2 \cos \left(\theta\right)+g l^3 m_p^3 \sin ^2\left(\theta\right) \cos \left(\theta\right)+\frac{l^2 m_p \mathrm{p}_1^2}{2}-l m_p \mathrm{p}_1 \mathrm{p}_2 \cos \left(\theta\right)+\frac{m_c \mathrm{p}_2^2}{2}+\frac{m_p \mathrm{p}_2^2}{2}}{l^2 m_p\left(m_c+m_p \sin ^2\left(\theta\right)\right)} $

Dynamical equations

The dynamical equations are calculated using Hamilton’s equations. It is shown below

$\begin{equation} \cfrac{\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{q_j}}{\mathrm{d} t}=\cfrac{\partial H}{\partial \boldsymbol{p_j}}, \quad \cfrac{\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{p_j}}{\mathrm{d} t}=-\cfrac{\partial H}{\partial \boldsymbol{q_j}} + Q_{nc} \end{equation}$

Here $Q_{nc}$ represents and non-conservative force acting on the system, $q_j$ represents a single generalised position and $p_j$ the conjugate momentum. The non non-conservative could be a control input. Plugging in our Hamiltonian into Hamilton’s equations results in an incredibly complicated set of equations, which cannot be shown here. It is calculated in the notebook here.

These set of equations are first order and can be solved using numerical integration. In this system, the Hamiltonian (Total energy) is a constant of motion, so the integration scheme must take this into account to ensure minimal deviation from the system. These family of integrators are called symplectic integrators [3]. If we just require a very rough estimate of the motion, then schemes such as Runge-Kutta are useful.

Conclusion

This article gave a brief discussion on deriving the dynamics of a cart-pendulum using the Hamiltonian formulation. The code I used to derive the equations are given in this link here. The equations we get are way more conplicated that those we get using the Lagrangian Formulation (discussed here), nevertheless, this article is an exercise is using Hamiltonian dynamics.

Reference

[1] Wikipedia: Hamiltonian mechanics
[2] Classical Mechanics: Hamiltonian dynamics, V Balakrishnan
[3] Wikipedia: Symplectic integrator
